I've updated my PR for https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/4758 so please review/test if you have some time...

Regression: Fieldset style broken · Issue #4758 · backdrop/backdrop-issues
(Still looking into this, but wanted to quickly create an issue for it) I've noticed certain styles broken with fieldsets: "Formatter options" fieldsets under CKEditor-enabled fields ...

...there's only one small thing that needs fixing (a gap between the CKEditor and the "Formatting options" fieldset), but I need to take a break now. ...if anyone has capacity, please feel free to take my PR and improve the CSS and/or try to fix that annoying gap.
float (left|right depending on language direction) on the legend element does the trick for me, but I'm not sure if this breaks something else.

.js fieldset.collapsible legend {
  float: left;
}
.js[dir="rtl"] fieldset.collapsible legend {
  float: right;
}

...but it seems a little "jumpy" when collapsing/expanding...

The jumpy thing is pre-existing @indigoxela : https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/3596

Formatting options: flickering fieldset expand/collapse animation · Issue #3596 · backdrop/backdrop-issues
This is a follow-up to #3516... When expanding/collapsing the fieldset, there is this subtle "jump" in the animation, which doesn't happen when expanding/collapsing other, "regul...

Ah, OK.
The "float" trick doesn't seem to break the overflow thing again. Wanna give it a try?
Already am :sweat_smile:
...it works :+1:
...just trying to see if I can make things a little less "jumpy"
PR updated @indigoxela ++
indigoxela Cheers (Karma: 9)
@jenlampton your CSS skills are way better than mine, so can you please have a look when you can?
@wesruv you are being missed :sweat_smile: :heart:
@klonos I could close my PR, I think a full revert isn't necessary anymore. Do you agree?
Yup :+1: ...althoughit might be possible to improve the CSS introduced in the PR, we could have a follow-up to clean that up. In the meantime, things seem to be fixed with my PR.
Opened a follow-up issue. Seems we're still having fieldset problems...

https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/4766

Fix fieldset styling · Issue #4766 · backdrop/backdrop-issues
Description of the bug This started in #3930 and was 'fixed' in #4758. But there are still issues with the styling of fieldsets. Specifically non-collapsible ones: Steps To Reproduce To rep...
Sorry I missed your ping @klonos ty for opening the follow up @BWPanda
Maybe we need automated visual regression tests. No idea how easy that is to set up for a project.

Hmm... Backdrop/Drupal uses Simpletest for PHP unit tests (for making sure functions work as expected, etc.). And I've personally written/used Behat tests in D8 for testing a website's interactivity (e.g. click this button, make sure you see this message). But I've not heard of visual regression tests... Sounds like you're wanting to test CSS code. Is that even a thing?

@BWPanda for a while there was lots of talk at Drupal Camps about Backstop JS a visual regression tool that takes screenshots of your website and then compares the screenshots to baseline images taken in the past and flags any unexpected changes.

https://garris.github.io/BackstopJS/

Pretty cool idea, but I've never used in practice.
Ha! Cool.
Very cool idea. I always wanted to put it into practice, but never found the time and project get it working.
I've used a bit for individual sites but not for projects. It's actually an easy way to find out if some things break instead of writing functional tests. Though obviously isn't as thorough
We have been using https://diffy.website in the agency I work for. ...there's another one, but keep forgetting the name.
Pantheon bought a tool that was made for WordPress and they're going to roll it out for Drupal too. I can't recall the name either
Is someone talking about Wordpress again?
Not sure if it's possible, but what about using pure CSS animation for the fieldset instead of JS?
Yeah, I think that the blocker for doing that is that we've inherited things from D7, and that there isn't (wasn't?) wide browser support for CSS transitions back then.
No longer bound by the "Drupal Way" right? :wink:
I guess not, but we still need to consider browser support and make sure that if we replace JS with CSS we're not breaking things for 80% of the people using the software...
...we need to keep one eye on everything outlined in https://backdropcms.org/philosophy

Not sure if it's possible, but what about using pure CSS animation for the fieldset instead of JS

Or the html5 details element instead of fieldsets, we already have an issue for that: https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/324

Add the HTML details element to core form API · Issue #324 · backdrop/backdrop-issues
